newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES LARGELY FIRMER ON WEDNESDAY.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES LARGELY FIRMER ON WEDNESDAY.

text.p: Zimbabwe's short-term money rates edged up from their previous levels in Wednesday's fairly tight market, dealers said.

They said the central Reserve Bank had already mopped up the day's maturities through a Z$200 million treasury bill auction which yielded an average rate of 23.34 percent. This compared with a rate of 23.12 percent at the second of two similar auctions held on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, on the secondary market, treasury bills were being traded at 22.75 percent, up from 22.25 percent while call money held steady at 20 percent.

NCD bills with 30-, 60- and 90-day maturities were quoted at 25 and 24 percent (buying and selling respectively) from 25 and 22 percent. Bank acceptance bills were being bought at 24.25 percent from 23.5 percent and their selling rate also firmed to 23.5 from 22.25 percent.
